subject: Ethics
title: Torture and the Ticking Bomb
description: A micro-lesson that makes Torture and the Ticking Bomb usable.

hook.text: A terrorist planted a nuclear bomb in a city. You caught him. He won't talk. Is torture justified?

buildup.text: The ticking bomb scenario argues that torture can be moral when millions of lives are at stake.

discovery.text: Defenders say extreme situations justify extreme measures. One person's pain versus a city's survival.

twist.text: The scenario is designed to make torture seem logical. In reality, torture produces unreliable information.

climax.text: If you allow torture once, you've created a legal precedent. The exception becomes the rule.

punchline.text: The hypothetical is simple. Real torture never is.

quiz.question: What is the main practical objection to the ticking bomb torture argument?
options: Torture is too expensive and time-consuming to be effective under time pressure
Most terrorists are trained to resist torture indefinitely
In reality, torture produces unreliable information and creates dangerous legal precedents
